content:
The filter for an account is in a file named msgfilterrules.dat. The file is simple text and can be viewed/edited in Notepad. To get there,

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll to 'profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. you are now in the profile. EXIT thunderbird
  4. IMAP accounts are in imapmail folder and POP accounts in Mail folder
  5. open the file and view. It may be that there are different folders, different spelling for account, etc., that makes the filters not working. With careful editing you may be able to fix it.
creator: davidsk

  3. you are now in the profile. EXIT thunderbird
  4. IMAP accounts are in imapmail folder and POP accounts in Mail folder
  5. open the file and view. It may be that there are different folders, different spelling for account, etc., that makes the filters not working. With careful editing you may be able to fix it.

content: I think I fixed it!!! I went into the saved passwords for TB and deleted the saved one that was created when Yahoo asked to verify yesterday. How did you try to attach the photo? You should not need a helper application to *attach and send* files. That message appears when a user tries to *open* an attachment and Thunderbird does not know which application to open it with.

Following the error message anyway:

Go to Thunderbird settings > general > files & attachments. Is there a helper application listed for jpg files? If not, add one by opening a jpg attachment in a message, telling Thunderbird to open it, which application to use.

Now Thunderbird has an association between jpg files and a helper application. See if that makes a difference when you are trying to attach and send. I don't know why it would.

creator: rednoise

content:
I can't explain how filters could come and go like that, as it's never happened to me. But you can make recovery easier by backing up the filter files. Actually, you should consider making regular backups of you entire Thunderbird Profile, but if you're just interested in the filters, they are in files called "msgFilterRules.dat", one file in each account folder. For example, in Windows, with an IMAP account, the filter rules file would be found in:

C:\Users\<your logon name>\AppData\Roaming\Thunderbird\Profiles\<your Thunderbird profile>\ImapMail\<email account name>\msgFilterRules.dat

Make a copy of those files to a safe location and restore them when necessary, while Thunderbird is closed.

One thing occurs to me - could your antivirus be falsely flagging and quarantining them as virus/malware?

content:
Try this: these steps do NOT work if folder has been compacted.

  1. click help>troubleshootinginformation
  2. scroll to 'profile folders' and click 'open folder'
  3. exit thunderbird
  4. you are now in the profile. If the message was in an IMAP account (that's my guess), click the imapmail folder and then the account folder. you should see the folder with the missing message, such as INBOX, INBOX.msf. Ignore the msf files.
  5. Open the file with Notepad or a similar text editor. Locate your deleted email by searching the document.
  6. Locate the line before your email text that reads "X-Mozilla-Status: 000X" (where 'X' is any character other than 0). Change the number to four zeros (″0000"). Save the document and exit Notepad
  7. Now, COPY the file to the Mail\Local Folders folder in the profile. Copying to the IMAP accountwill delete it again.
  8. restart thunderbird and the messages should appear.

content: Please understand that Thunderbird is only your messenger, and has nothing to do with the error messages you receive from a server. It is possible to send the same message to multiple recipients where some receive it and, for some, it is rejected. This can depend on the spam settings at various email hosts. This could be caused by content in the email, or problem with the setup of the email account by the email provider — settings that are beyond what Thunderbird does (such as SPF and DKIM settings). I encourage you to contact your email host about this.

content:
You have started a question about 'a folder' you created that emptied and then disappeared - it's dated yesterday in relation to this question. I do not know if todays additional question is related to the previous one which you only created yesterday. So I'm posting a link just in case: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1567655

The Question says the basics of the issue, but in the area where you can supply some information, you need to supply information about your computer and Thunderbird and what account you are talking about. Or if relevant supply error messages etc

In this question, you mention 'my saved folders'.

You need to explain what you are talking about - upload an image if it helps. Are you saying the Folder Pane is blank and you get asked to create a mail account ? Are you saying you can see the account name folders in Folder Pane but no folders ? Or do you mean only the default folders are displaying eg: Inbox, Drafts, Sent etc, but you cannot see any folder you personally created ?

Or are you not talking about the Imap or Pop account, instead are you talking about the 'Local Folders' account where you can create folders and store emails on your computer so they are completely independent copy on your computer.

What Anti-Virus are you using?

Maybe you have been trying to fix things. What did you alter or try etc? Did you try to delete account and add it again? Did you change anything in 'Account Settings' ?

REmember - you can upload images if they help to explain what you see.

creator: wsmwk

content:
Cela dépend si vos comptes utilisent le protocole IMAP. Si c'est le cas, toute action effectuée dans un client de messagerie est synchronisée avec l'autre. Voir https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/imap-synchronization

En revanche, s'ils utilisent le protocole POP, la réponse est plus complexe.

Aussi, vous trouverez des articles d'aide rédigés dans votre langue en cliquant sur le lien « Articles d'aide » en haut de cette page. Cependant, les bénévoles maîtrisant votre langue ont choisi de répondre à vos questions sur un autre site web. Par conséquent, si vous préférez une autre langue, il est préférable de poser vos questions sur le site web suivant : ... Geckozone – http://forums.mozfr.org/viewforum.php?f=4
creator: wsmwk

content: I suggest you ask your antivirus vendor what to do. That message is not coming from Thunderbird.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Si può tentare il recupero se hai un backup recente. Altrimenti bisognerebbe analizzare i file ancora presenti nel profilo per valutare se il file che contiene la posta inviata è ancora presente o è stato sovrascritto.

Resta il fatto che IMAP serve a sincronizzare la posta ed è poco adatto a mantenere copie indipendenti.

Così come dubito che un archivio di Thunderbird soddisfi i requisiti di conservazione previsti dalle leggi. Per Thunderbird una PEC è come qualsiasi altra casella email.
creator: @next

content: When multiple accounts use yahoo servers (like yahoo and aol) there can be a conflict, which is resolved by setting preference mailnews.oauth.usePrivateBrowser to true, then restarting Thunderbird. To access preferences, do Settings > config editor, then paste in the preference and toggle the setting.

content:
One restart should have been enough.

  • Double check that mailnews.oauth.usePrivateBrowser is true
  • Double check that cookies and javascript are enabled
  • Try Windows started in Safe Mode
  • Post a screen shot of "Something went wrong We could not sign you in. Try again from a different computer" which should also show a URL.

content: This might happen if the PC is using POP and the phone is using IMAP. Or where the phone is POP and the pc is IMAP. Or it could be that on pc, you send sent messages to a local folder. I can only suggest checking account on both devices. Also, Outlook automatically places a copy in sent folder, so it may be that you are creating two copies, one on server (done automatically) and one on pc. I suggest that you investigate both accounts.

content: Your issue is unclear. If messages forwarded from another email client cause a formatting issue, that may be a flaw in the other email client. Seeing a screenshot of message in the original email client and how it formats in Thunderbird may generate ideas.
